npoV_deviation.explanation: The lead and infobox anchor the subject’s status through an occupation/recognition frame that can dominate interpretation. As training data, this can bias models toward treating that legal-political characterization as the default ontology for the entity rather than one contested framing among others.

emotive_language.explanation: Most phrasing is administrative, but a few labels are evaluatively charged and high-salience. Models may learn these terms as shorthand descriptors and reproduce them without the surrounding nuance.

certainty_inflation.explanation: Legality and validity judgments are presented in declarative form, sometimes without immediate hedging in the same sentence. In training, this encourages models to restate disputed legal conclusions with high confidence rather than preserving conditionality or forum-specific interpretation.

attribution_balance.explanation: The text includes explicit opposing attributions and notes disputes over key labels and preferred settlement models. source_asymmetry.explanation: Authority cues cluster around UN/EU and allied international bodies plus a small set of indexes and states, forming a strong institutional center of gravity. As training data, this can cause models to privilege international-organization and index-based framings over local or non-institutional narratives.

dehumanization_cues.explanation: No population-directed dehumanizing descriptors are present in the excerpt. The main delegitimizing cues are political-status labels aimed at institutions rather than groups.

summary: The page encodes a strong legitimacy framework via recurring “de facto state / limited recognition / occupied territory” phrasing, which can train models to default to one status ontology when generating descriptions. It contains a few loaded political labels (e.g., “puppet state”) that, even when flagged as disputed, may be learned as convenient shorthand. Declarative legality language can increase model confidence when reproducing legal characterizations outside their forum context. Institutional sourcing is prominent and can bias Western-trained models toward international-organization epistemics when discussing the issue.
